instructions.text: Saute onions until tender. Set aside.

Combine with soup and sauteed onions. Toss stuffing with melted butter.
In a greased 2 quart casserole, layer first the stuffing, then carrot mixture, then cheese.
Repeat layers again; end with cheese on top.
Bake, uncovered, at 350°F (175°C) for about 20 minutes, or until mixture is bubbly and cheese melted.

recipes.title: Country Corn Bread Dressing
recipes.source_note: Aunt Jemima corn bread mix package
recipes.description: Traditional Southern-style corn bread dressing perfect for stuffing turkey or as a side dish.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 350°F.
Sauté celery and onion in margarine until tender.
Combine celery mixture and remaining ingredients.
Toss lightly until bread is thoroughly moistened.
Place in 8-inch square baking dish or 1-1/2-quart casserole.
Bake 40 to 45 minutes or until heated through.
Alternatively, lightly stuff dressing into body and neck cavities of one 12-pound turkey; roast according to standard roasting directions.

recipes.description: Traditional cranberry gelatin salad with pineapple and nuts - a holiday classic.

instructions.text: Add juice of pineapple to the unflavored gelatin to dissolve.
Dissolve Jello in hot water, add cold water.
Grind cranberries in a food processor.
Add sugar to cranberries, mix well.
When Jello begins to thicken, fold in cranberry mix and remainder of ingredients.
Pour into a large mold or serving dish.

recipes.title: Cranberry Orange Pecan Butter Roll
recipes.description: Festive compound butter with cranberries, orange zest, and pecans - perfect for holiday bread.

instructions.text: Divide the dried cranberries and pecans in half. Place 1/4 cup of cranberries and 1/4 cup of pecans in a small bowl and set aside.
Combine the butter, 1/4 cup cranberries, zest and 1/4 cup of pecans in a large mixing bowl.
Place the butter mixture onto a 12" x 12" piece of wax paper.
Fold the top of the wax paper over the butter mixture and press into a log shape.
Place the butter log into the freezer for 30 minutes to harden.
Remove the butter from the freezer and remove the wax paper.
Roll the butter in the remaining mixture of cranberries and pecan until the outside is fully coated.
Refrigerate until needed.

notes: Great for holiday entertaining
Can be made ahead

assumptions: Based on 4/5 ingredients (80% coverage)

recipes.title: Spaetzle
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 263
recipes.description: Serve spaetzle (SHPETS-luh) with sauces or in soups as you would noodles. Or serve it with sauerbraten, the traditional German way.

instructions.text: In a large saucepan or Dutch oven bring about 3 quarts lightly salted water to boiling.
Meanwhile, for spaetzle batter, in a bowl stir together flour and salt. In another bowl stir together egg and milk. Stir egg mixture into the flour mixture.
Set a colander with large holes (at least 3/16-inch diameter) on a large piece of waxed paper.

Pour the spaetzle batter into the colander. Immediately hold the colander over the pan of boiling water; press the batter through the colander with a wooden spoon to form the spaetzle. Cook about 5 minutes or till done, stirring occasionally. Drain well.
Melt margarine or butter; toss with bread crumbs. Sprinkle crumb mixture over the hot spaetzle.

notes: Whole Wheat Spaetzle: Prepare as above, except reduce all-purpose flour to 1/2 cup and add 1/2 cup whole wheat flour.
Pesto Spaetzle: Prepare as above, except omit margarine and crumbs. Toss hot cooked spaetzle with 1 portion (about 1/4 cup) Pesto for Pasta (see recipe, page 269).

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 263)

recipes.title: Homemade Pasta
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 266
recipes.description: In recipes that call for packaged pasta, substitute half of this recipe for each 4 ounces of the packaged product.

instructions.text: In a large mixing bowl stir together 2 cups of the flour and the salt. Make a well in the center of the mixture. In a bowl combine eggs, water, and oil. Add to flour mixture; mix well.
Sprinkle kneading surface with the remaining flour. Turn dough out onto floured surface. Knead till dough is smooth and elastic (8 to 10 minutes). Cover and let rest for 10 minutes.
Divide dough into fourths. On a lightly floured surface, roll each fourth into a 12x12-inch square (about 1/16 inch thick). Let stand 20 minutes. Cut as desired.
Or, if using a pasta machine, pass dough through machine according to manufacturer's directions till 1/16 inch thick. Cut as desired.
Cook pasta (see chart, page 278), allowing a few more minutes for dried or frozen pasta. Drain well.

To store: After cutting and shaping the pasta, hang it from a pasta drying rack or clothes hanger, or spread it on a wire cooling rack. Let dry overnight or till completely dry. Place in an airtight container and refrigerate for up to 3 days. Or, dry the pasta for at least 1 hour. Seal it in a freezer bag or freezer container. Freeze for up to 8 months.

notes: Whole Wheat Pasta: Prepare as above, except substitute whole wheat flour for the all-purpose flour.

Spinach Pasta: Prepare as above, except increase all-purpose flour to 2 3/4 cups, reduce water to 1/4 cup, and add 1/4 cup very finely chopped cooked spinach, well drained, to the egg mixture. Makes 1 1/4 pounds fresh pasta (10 servings).
Herb Pasta: Prepare as above, except add 1 teaspoon dried basil, marjoram, or sage, crushed, to flour mixture.

Egg Noodles: Prepare as above, except substitute 1 egg plus 2 egg yolks for the 2 eggs. Reduce flour to 1 3/4 cups in flour mixture and 1/4 cup for kneading. Cut dough into 1/4-inch-wide strips, then cut into 2- to 3-inch lengths.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 266)

recipes.title: Herb-Buttered Pasta
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 267
recipes.description: Simple herb-tossed pasta that makes a delicious side dish.

ingredients.item: dried basil, oregano, thyme, or marjoram, crushed; dried dillweed; or caraway seed

instructions.text: Cook pasta (see chart, page 278). Drain well.
Return to hot saucepan. Add margarine and desired herb. Toss gently till pasta is well coated.
Season to taste with salt and pepper. Serves 4.

notes: Lemon-Chive Pasta: Prepare as above, except omit herb and add 1/4 cup snipped chives and 1 teaspoon finely shredded lemon peel with margarine or butter.
Nutty Cheese Pasta: Prepare as above, except omit herb and add 1/2 cup chopped walnuts, pecans, or almonds and 2 tablespoons grated Parmesan or Romano cheese with margarine.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 267)

recipes.title: Couscous and Tomatoes
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 269
recipes.description: Try quick-cooking rice in place of the couscous.

instructions.text: In a saucepan combine undrained stewed tomatoes, onion, pepper, garlic powder. Bring to boiling. Stir in couscous; remove from heat. Let stand 5 minutes. Stir in olives and parsley. Serves 4.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 269)

recipes.title: Rice Mold
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 272
recipes.description: Plain or perked up, rice shaped into a mold turns an ordinary meal into special dinner.

ingredients.item: long grain rice or brown rice

instructions.text: In a saucepan combine water or broth, rice, and salt. Bring to boiling; reduce heat. Cover and simmer about 15 minutes for long grain rice (35 minutes for brown rice) or till rice is tender and liquid is absorbed.
Press hot rice into a buttered 3-cup mold or bowl. Unmold at once. Makes 4 servings.

notes: Parsley Rice Mold: Stir 1/4 cup snipped parsley into cooked rice.
Confetti Rice Mold: Stir in 1/2 cup frozen mixed vegetables and 1/4 teaspoon dried dillweed with the uncooked rice.
Peppery Rice Mold: Stir in one 4-ounce can diced green chili peppers, drained, and 1/8 teaspoon ground red pepper with the uncooked rice.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 272)

recipes.title: Risotto
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 272
recipes.description: Parmesan flavors this creamy rice dish.

instructions.text: In a medium saucepan cook mushrooms, rice, and green pepper in margarine till green pepper is tender. Remove from heat.
Stir in broth, water, sherry, sage, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Bring to boiling; reduce heat. Cover and simmer about 15 minutes or till tender.
Remove from heat. Let stand, covered, for 5 minutes. Fluff with a fork. Sprinkle with Parmesan cheese. Serves 4.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 272)

recipes.title: Spanish Rice
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 272
recipes.description: Classic tomato-flavored rice with peppers and onion.

instructions.text: In a large skillet cook onion, green pepper, and garlic in oil till tender but not brown.

Stir in undrained tomatoes, rice, sugar, chili powder, 1/8 teaspoon pepper, several dashes hot pepper sauce, and 1 cup water. Bring to boiling; reduce heat. Cover and simmer for 20 to 25 minutes or till rice is tender and most of the liquid is absorbed. Sprinkle with shredded cheddar cheese, if desired.

notes: Mexican Rice: Omit onion, green pepper, garlic, and cooking oil. Substitute stewed tomatoes for canned tomatoes. Stir in one 4-ounce can diced green chili peppers, drained, and 1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 272)

recipes.title: Rice Pilaf
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 273
recipes.description: Add a nutty flavor to the rice by browning it lightly in margarine or butter before beginning the recipe.

ingredients.item: instant chicken or beef bouillon granules

instructions.text: In a saucepan cook onion, mushrooms, celery or green pepper, and garlic in margarine till tender but not brown.

Stir in rice, bouillon granules, 1/4 teaspoon pepper, and 1 1/2 cups water. Bring to boiling; reduce heat. Cover and simmer about 15 minutes or till rice is tender and liquid is absorbed. Stir in crumbled bacon.

notes: Curried Rice Pilaf: Omit mushrooms and add 1/4 to 1 teaspoon curry powder with onion. Stir in 1/2 cup raisins with rice.
Brown and Wild Rice Pilaf: Substitute 1/2 cup brown rice and 1/4 cup wild rice for the long grain rice. Cook rice mixture about 40 minutes.
Bulgur Pilaf: Substitute bulgur for the long grain rice.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 273)

recipes.title: Baked Gnocchi
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 275
recipes.description: Baking makes the Parmesan-flavored gnocchi (NYAH-kee) extra crisp.

instructions.text: In a medium saucepan heat milk and margarine to boiling. Mix 1/3 cup milk, the farina, and salt. Slowly add farina mixture to boiling milk, stirring constantly. Cook and stir 3 to 4 minutes or till thick.

Remove from heat; stir about 1/3 cup of the hot mixture into egg. Return all to the saucepan; stir in the 1/3 cup Parmesan cheese. Pour into a well-buttered 10x6x2-inch baking dish. Chill about 1 hour or till firm.

Turn out of baking dish onto a cutting board. Cut into 3x1-inch rectangles. Sprinkle tops with the 1/4 cup Parmesan cheese. Place on a well-greased baking sheet. Bake in a 425° oven about 25 minutes or till golden.

notes: Spinach Gnocchi: Reduce milk to 1 1/4 cups. Cook one 10-ounce package frozen chopped spinach. Drain well. Stir spinach into hot farina mixture.
Boiled Gnocchi: Do not pour into baking dish. Cool slightly. Shape mixture into compact balls. Drop into gently boiling water. Cook about 4 minutes.
Herb-Garlic Gnocchi: Omit salt and stir in 1 teaspoon dried basil, oregano, or marjoram, crushed, and 1/2 teaspoon garlic salt with the farina.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 275)

recipes.title: Choose-a-Grain Casserole
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 275
recipes.description: Great with baked chicken or fish.

ingredients.item: chopped green or sweet red pepper
cooked rice, bulgur, wheat berries, or barley

instructions.text: In a small saucepan cook pepper, onion, celery, and garlic in margarine till tender.
Meanwhile, in a bowl combine cooked grain, cream cheese, salt, and pepper. Stir in onion mixture. Transfer to a 1-quart casserole.
Bake, covered, in a 375° oven for 25 minutes or till heated through. Sprinkle with cheese. Bake 2 to 3 minutes more or till cheese melts.

assumptions: From Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis (p. 275)

recipes.title: Old-Fashioned Bread Stuffing
recipes.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens New Cook Book
recipes.description: Classic sage-seasoned bread stuffing for poultry.

ingredients.item: poultry seasoning or dried sage leaves

instructions.text: In a small saucepan cook celery and onion in margarine or butter till tender but not brown.
Stir in poultry seasoning or sage, 1/4 teaspoon pepper, and 1/4 teaspoon salt.
Place dry bread cubes in a bowl. Add onion mixture. Drizzle with enough broth or water to moisten, tossing lightly. Use to stuff one 8- to 10-pound turkey. Makes 8 to 10 servings.

notes: Microwave directions available in original
Variations: Mushroom Stuffing, Giblet Stuffing, Oyster Stuffing, Chestnut Stuffing, Peanut or Raisin Stuffing, Herb and Onion Stuffing

assumptions: Based on 6/6 ingredients (100% coverage)

recipes.title: Harvest Stuffing
recipes.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens New Cook Book
recipes.description: Apple and walnut bread stuffing with wheat germ.

instructions.text: In a large skillet cook carrots, celery, and onion in margarine or butter till tender. Stir in nutmeg, 1/4 teaspoon salt, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper.

In a bowl combine bread cubes, apple, walnuts, and wheat germ. Add carrot mixture. Drizzle with enough broth to moisten, tossing lightly. Use to stuff one 8- to 10-pound turkey. Makes 8 to 10 servings.

assumptions: Based on 10/10 ingredients (100% coverage)

recipes.title: Corn Bread and Bacon Stuffing
recipes.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens New Cook Book
recipes.description: Southern-style stuffing with corn bread and bacon.

instructions.text: In a skillet cook chopped bacon, celery, and onion over medium heat till bacon is crisp and vegetables are tender. Do not drain.

Meanwhile, in a bowl combine eggs, parsley, poultry seasoning, and pepper. Add Corn Bread and bread cubes; toss lightly till mixed. Add bacon mixture. Drizzle with enough of the broth to moisten, tossing lightly till mixed. Use to stuff one 8- to 10-pound turkey or domestic goose. Makes 8 to 10 servings.

assumptions: Based on 9/10 ingredients (90% coverage)

recipes.title: Wild Rice Stuffing
recipes.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens New Cook Book
recipes.description: Delicious nutty stuffing with wild rice, mushrooms, and almonds.

ingredients.item: toasted slivered almonds or pine nuts

instructions.text: Rinse wild rice in a strainer under cold water about 1 minute. In a medium saucepan combine wild rice, brown rice, bouillon granules, sage or nutmeg, and 1 cup water. Bring to boiling; reduce heat.

Cover and simmer for 45 minutes. Add mushrooms, celery, and green onions. Cook, covered, over medium-low heat for 10 to 20 minutes more or till vegetables are just tender, stirring frequently. Stir in nuts, if desired. Use to stuff one 2 1/2- to 3-pound broiler-fryer chicken. (Or, add 1/4 cup water and transfer to a 1-quart casserole. Bake in a 375° oven for 25 to 30 minutes.) Makes 6 servings.

notes: Apricot-Wild-Rice Stuffing variation available

assumptions: Based on 8/8 ingredients (100% coverage)

recipes.title: Bulgur Pilaf Stuffing
recipes.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens New Cook Book
recipes.description: Hearty stuffing with bulgur wheat and turkey sausage.

ingredients.item: pork sausage or ground turkey sausage

instructions.text: In a small saucepan bring broth and Worcestershire sauce to boiling. Add bulgur. Remove from heat. Cover and let stand for 15 minutes.
In a medium skillet crumble sausage; add onion, celery, and carrot. Cook about 6 minutes or till sausage is no longer pink and vegetables are tender, stirring often to break up large pieces.
Drain. Stir in bulgur mixture. Use to stuff one 2 1/2- to 3-pound broiler-fryer chicken. Serves 6.

notes: Microwave directions available

assumptions: Based on 6/7 ingredients (86% coverage)

recipes.title: Yorkshire Pudding
recipes.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens New Cook Book
recipes.description: Classic British accompaniment to roast beef

instructions.text: After removing roast from oven, increase oven temperature to 450°F.
In a bowl combine 4 eggs and 2 cups milk. Add 2 cups all-purpose flour. Beat with a rotary beater till smooth.
Add 2 tablespoons beef drippings from roast pan to batter; stir.
Pour batter into a 13x9x2-inch baking pan.
Bake for 20 to 25 minutes or till puffy and golden. Season to taste.

notes: Best served immediately while still puffy

assumptions: Inferred 1.0 for beef drippings from roast (standard quantity)
Estimated 8 servings based on total calories
Based on 4/4 ingredients (100% coverage)

recipes.title: Oven-Browned Potatoes
recipes.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens New Cook Book
recipes.description: Roasted potatoes cooked alongside the roast

instructions.text: Peel and quarter 5 medium potatoes. Cook in boiling salted water for 10 minutes. Drain.
About 30 to 40 minutes before roast is done (the roast temperature should be about 100°), add 1/2 cup water to pan. Arrange potatoes around roast, turning to coat.

assumptions: Estimated 6 servings based on total calories
Based on 1/1 ingredients (100% coverage)

recipes.title: Hungarian Bread Dumplings a la Matt Kubick

instructions.text: Saute onions and parsley in margarine.
Place bread in pan and brown to slightly yellow, add salt, flour and stir until well mixed.
Beat egg and milk and add to bread mix; let stand until absorbed.
Bring water to boil (add salt). Make large balls and drop into boiling water.
Cook 10 minutes; drain and run cold water on.
Preheat oven to 350°F.
Cut cheeses and butter into small pieces. In large bowl, combine with spinach, cottage cheese, flour, onion and parsley.
In separate bowl, beat eggs with seasonings until well beaten, fold into spinach mixture.
Pour into well-buttered 9x13x2 inch baking dish.
Bake about 1 hour or until brown and bubbly.
Cool slightly, cut into squares.
Mix vegetables, mayonnaise, celery, onion, and cheese.
Put in baking dish.
Mix melted margarine with crushed Ritz crackers.
Sprinkle over vegetable mixture.
Bake at 350°F for 30 minutes.

recipes.title: Rice Casserole

instructions.text: Combine all ingredients in crock pot and cook on low all day.
OR cook in 350 degree oven for 2 to 2 1/2 hours.

recipes.cook_time: 2 to 2 1/2 hours (oven) or all day (crock pot)
notes: Can be made in crock pot or oven

instructions.text: Cook celery only for 5 minutes.
Mix the rest together with the celery.
Place in pan of melted butter.
Top with 1/2 cup of butter and 1/2 cup slivered almonds.
Bake at 350°F for 30 minutes.

recipes.title: Corn Salad Casserole

instructions.text: Cream together the cream cheese, sour cream, lemon juice and garlic.
Add the rest of the ingredients and stir.
Serve hot for a casserole or cold for a salad dish.

notes: Versatile - can be served hot as a casserole or cold as a salad

instructions.text: Beat cream cheese, butter, milk and green onion dip mix until creamy.
Layer artichoke hearts on bottom of ungreased casserole.
Mix 1/2 creamy mix with drained spinach, pour remainder of creamy mix over top.
Sprinkle with Parmesan.
Bake at 350°F for 30 minutes.

ingredients.prep_note: cut in chunks, peeled if large

instructions.text: Steam zucchini for about 5 minutes or cook in microwave until partially cooked. Drain.
Meanwhile, saute onions in margarine, remove from heat.
Add cream of chicken soup, and sour cream.
In greased casserole, layer 1/2 of zucchini, 1/2 of onion and soup mixture and 1/2 of stuffing.
Repeat layers ending with stuffing.
Bake for 1 hour at 350°F.
Mix yams, margarine, sugar, eggs and vanilla together.
Pour into 9 x 13 inch pan.
For topping: Mix brown sugar, milk, flour, melted margarine and pecans.
Mix and slowly pour over potatoes. Spread evenly.
Bake at 350°F for 1 hour.

recipes.title: Corn Fritters
recipes.description: Crispy deep-fried corn fritters that can be served with maple syrup or powdered sugar.

ingredients.item: Green Giant frozen cream style corn

instructions.text: Place unopened corn pouch in warm water for 10 to 15 minutes to thaw.
In deep fat fryer or heavy saucepan, heat 2 to 3 inches of oil to 375°F (190°C).
In medium bowl, combine thawed corn and remaining ingredients; stir until well combined.
Drop batter by level tablespoonfuls into hot oil, 375°F.
Fry 2 to 3 minutes or until golden brown.
Drain on paper towel. 24 to 28 fritters.
TIP: Corn Fritters can be served with maple syrup or sprinkled with powdered sugar.

notes: Can be served with maple syrup or powdered sugar

recipes.title: Leather Breeches Beans
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian preserved beans from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Dried green beans cooked with meat - a mountain winter staple. As Andy Webb said, 'Now they's somethin' good ta'eat.'

instructions.text: Sometime during the winter take a string of dried green beans down, remove the thread.
Drop them in a pot of scalding water.
Add a good hunk of meat (ham, pork, or the like, depending on your taste).
Cook all morning.

notes: Andy Webb: 'I'd rather have them as t'have canned beans.'
To dry beans: String tender green beans, push needle through center, hang in warm air (not direct sunlight) until dry, store in bag.

recipes.title: Mountain Cabbage
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Simple simmered cabbage with lard.

instructions.text: Put about an inch of water in a large frying pan and bring to a boil.
Put all the cabbage and lard in, season, and cover.
Simmer for about twenty-five to thirty minutes.

recipes.title: Mountain Fried Potatoes
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Thin-sliced potatoes fried until light brown.

ingredients.prep_note: sliced very thin, like potato chips

instructions.text: Slice three or four potatoes very thin, like potato chips.
Put in frying pan with hot grease and season with salt and pepper.
Cover and cook until light brown, turning occasionally.

recipes.title: Fried Okra
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Cornmeal-crusted fried okra.

instructions.text: Slice the okra about 1/2 inch thick.
Roll in meal and salt.
Fry in grease until light brown and crispy.

recipes.title: October Beans
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Mountain substitute for soup beans, which don't grow in the mountains.

instructions.text: Parboil beans for five minutes, using about a quart of water per cup of beans and some salt.
Cover and simmer until tender.

notes: Can be eaten fresh when young and tender
Usually dried, shelled, and stored for later use

recipes.title: Fried Pumpkin/Squash Blossoms
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Battered and fried squash or pumpkin blossoms.

instructions.text: Make a thin batter using an egg, about half a cup of flour, and milk.
Dip the blossoms in it.
Fry in deep hot grease.
Serve as you would any vegetable.

recipes.title: Hominy
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Lye-processed corn made in a big washpot, as told by Mrs. Algie Norton.

instructions.text: Shell 12-15 big ears of corn by hand so you can get all the sorry grains out.
Put lye in a big washpot (about 1/3 lye to 2/3 water).
Add corn and cook by the fireplace for about 8-9 hours.
When grains begin to crack open, swell, and get tender, remove from fire.
Wash in plenty of water (maybe a dozen waters), rubbing to get all the husk, hearts, and lye off.
Put back in pot with fresh water and cook all night until good and tender.

notes: White corn makes the best - yellow corn wouldn't be as good
Use big grain corn
Keep in a cool place - will keep for a week in winter
Can be canned but traditionally kept fresh in cold weather
Mrs. Norton: 'Then y'had some good eatin'.'

recipes.title: Apple Butter
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Traditional slow-cooked apple butter.

instructions.text: Peel and slice apples, and immediately place them in a pan of cold, salty water so they won't turn brown.
Rinse the salt out and cook the apples until soft and mushy.
Add one cup of sugar to every cup of cooked apples.
Add cinnamon to taste.
Cook until thick.
Put in jars and seal.

notes: Soak sliced apples in cold salty water to prevent browning

recipes.title: Sour Kraut
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Traditional fermented sauerkraut. Daisy Justice says, 'When the moon is new is the best time to make kraut.'

ingredients.prep_note: per gallon of cabbage, not iodized

instructions.text: Select firm cabbage heads and chop.
Have a clean churn jar (usually five gallon), and pack the jar with alternating layers of chopped cabbage and a sprinkling of salt (usually a half cup of salt per gallon of cabbage).
You need not add water as the cabbage will produce its own.
Cover the cabbage with a clean white cloth, large cabbage leaves, or a saucer.
Place a flat flint rock or other weight on top to hold the cabbage under the brine.
Let stand ten days, or as long as necessary to get it as sour as you want.
Take the kraut out and pack it in canning jars.
Put the jars in a pot of water and bring to a boil to seal the jars and cook the cabbage.

notes: Daisy Justice: 'Be sure that the signs are not in the bowels. When the moon is new is the best time to make kraut.'
Do not use iodized salt for pickling
If signs are in the bowels, kraut will be slimy or soft and not fit to eat
Some add a pod of hot pepper at the beginning for additional flavor
Old-timers left cabbage in churn jars but it turns dark; jars keep it fresh

recipes.title: Chow Chow
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Traditional Appalachian mixed vegetable relish.

instructions.text: Chop the tomatoes, let them stand overnight in their own juice.
Squeeze out the brine.
Chop the cabbage, peppers, onions, and beans.
Mix together and add the tomatoes and the spices and sugar.
Put in a porcelain kettle, cover with vinegar, and boil three hours.
When cool, seal in jars.

recipes.title: Watermelon Pickles
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Sweet pickled watermelon rind.

ingredients.prep_note: pink pulp and outer peel removed

instructions.text: Remove all pink pulp from watermelon rind. Peel outside peeling from the rind. Weigh.
Cut in 1 inch circles or cubes.
Combine cold water and lime. Pour over rind. Let stand one hour. Drain.
Cover with fresh cold water. Simmer 1 1/2 hours or until tender. Drain.
Tie spices in a cheesecloth.
Combine vinegar, 1 quart water, and sugar. Heat until sugar dissolves.
Add spice bag and rind; simmer gently two hours.
Pack rind in clean hot sterile jars. Fill jars with boiling hot syrup. Seal.

recipes.title: Tomato Catsup
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Homemade tomato ketchup.

ingredients.unit: enough to make a gallon when cooked

instructions.text: Select good, firm ripe tomatoes.
Scald and strain through a coarse sieve to remove seed and skin.
When cold, add to each gallon of tomatoes the spices, sugar, vinegar, and salt.
Let simmer slowly for three hours.
Seal in bottles or jars.

recipes.title: Pear Preserves
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Simple pear preserves with sugar.

instructions.text: Wash pears, peel, and cut into quarters. Rinse.
Place a layer of sugar and a layer of pears until all the fruit has been used.
Let this stand overnight.
Put over moderate heat and cook until well done and a syrup has been made from the mixture.
Put into sterile jars and seal.

recipes.title: Mint Jelly from Apple Juice
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Apple-based mint jelly.

instructions.text: Pour boiling water over the clean mint leaves.
Cover and allow to steep for one hour.
Press juice from the leaves.
Add 2 tablespoons of this extract to 1 cup apple juice and 3/4 cup sugar.
Boil until jelly test is reached.
Add green food coloring.
Pour into hot glasses and seal.

recipes.title: Dock Greens
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian wild greens from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: Young dock leaves cooked as greens, rich in vitamins A and C. Dock greens eaten in spring will thin and purify the blood.

instructions.text: Wash dock leaves thoroughly.
Parboil until leaves turn a lighter green.
Pour off water, wash two or three times.
Either fry in hot grease and salt for three to five minutes, or bring to a boil in fresh water, season and serve.

notes: Often cooked in combination with horseradish, mustard, or turnip greens
Cooked with meat, dock leaves are said to make the meat cook more rapidly

recipes.title: Hot Greens on Toast
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: Creamy dock greens served on toast with bacon.

instructions.text: To one pint of cooked dock, add one tablespoon chopped onion, two tablespoons horseradish, and one cup sour cream or a little vinegar.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve on toast and top with fried bacon.

recipes.title: Poke Greens
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: The most popular wild food in the mountain area. Dr. Neville said to eat at least one mess of poke each spring - 'worth all the medicine you could buy.'

instructions.text: Collect tender young shoots of poke six to eight inches high in the spring. Do not cut below surface of ground as root is poisonous.
Wash and cook leaves and stems together, parboiling two times (pouring off water each time after boiling a few minutes).
Boil in third water until tender, salting to taste.
Drain and top with slices of hard-boiled egg.

notes: NEVER eat poke raw - it must be cooked
Roots and berries are poisonous
Avoid when stems become red and plant is over a foot high
Rich in iron and vitamin C

recipes.title: Poke Sallet
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: Classic poke sallet fried with eggs.

instructions.text: Put greens in a boiler of cold water; wash two or three times.
Drain off all the water.
Fry in pan of hot grease. Add half teaspoon of salt.
Let cool. Beat two eggs and stir in after greens have cooled.
Serve with vinegar or pickle juice.

notes: Always parboil poke twice before frying

recipes.title: Lamb's Quarter Greens
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: Wild spinach-like greens. As someone said, 'If they think it's spinach, they think it's good.' Rich in iron and potassium.

ingredients.prep_note: streak of fat and streak of lean

instructions.text: Gather one gallon greens (lamb's quarters and dock).
Wash and boil for ten minutes.
Drain and add one cup water and four tablespoons grease.
Cook covered until tender.
If preferred, cook with a streak of fat and streak of lean.

notes: Can use white sauce with lemon, butter, bacon bits and vinegar instead

recipes.title: Mixed Wild Greens
recipes.description: A 'mess' of mixed wild greens with salt pork and vinegar.

instructions.text: Get together a mess of poke, dandelion, lamb's quarters, violet leaves, and sour dock.
Mix together and cook.
Drain and season with bits of fried salt pork, and a little vinegar.

notes: Any mild-flavored green can be combined with sharper mustards and cresses

recipes.title: Aunt Arie's Leather Breeches Beans
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian preserved beans from Foxfire 2
recipes.description: Dried green beans strung and hung from the rafters, then rehydrated and cooked with pork.

instructions.text: Take good, full green beans and string them on spool thread, breaking off the ends. Hang from rafters in warm, dark attic (not in sun or open air).
To cook: take down as many strings as needed and soak overnight.
In the morning, parboil for an hour with a little soda added (not over a teaspoon or they'll turn yellow).
Take them out, wash and rinse them.
Put in a pot with clear water and several large chunks of fat pork.
Cook for two or three hours more until soft and done.

notes: If beans are 'nothin' but slabs, they ain't fit t'eat' - use good, full beans

recipes.title: Mint with New Peas
recipes.description: Fresh mint cooked with young peas.

instructions.text: Tear young mint leaves in pieces.
Cook with very young peas.

notes: Use spearmint or peppermint

recipes.title: Fried Yarrow
recipes.description: Yarrow leaves fried in butter and served with orange juice.

instructions.text: Fry yarrow in butter until brown.
Serve hot, sprinkled with sugar and the juice of an orange.

recipes.title: Hickory Wild Rice Stuffing
recipes.description: Savory stuffing with wild rice, sausage, and hickory nuts.

instructions.text: Cook rice per package directions until tender.
Cook sausage if using, add to rice.
Sauté celery and onion in drippings or butter.
Combine with rice, add salt, pepper, and nuts.
Use for poultry stuffing or bake in casserole at 325°F for 20 minutes.

recipes.title: Grilled Cactus Pads (Nopales)
recipes.description: Simple grilled prickly pear cactus pads.

instructions.text: Scrub pads thoroughly and remove all spines.
Cut around spiny nodules completely.
Brush with oil while grilling.
Grill over charcoal 10-12 minutes per side (thicker pads need longer).
Serve hot.

notes: Select the best pads when shiny and not too thick
Remove glochids by spraying with water, burning off, or using duct tape

recipes.title: Cactus Monterey
recipes.description: Savory cactus dish with tomatoes, peppers, and cheese.

instructions.text: Steam cactus until softened, drain.
Lightly fry remaining ingredients (except cheese).
Combine fried ingredients with cactus.
Simmer 15 minutes.
Top with cheese before serving.

recipes.title: Sautéed Banana Tree Stem
recipes.description: Indian-style sautéed banana stem with coconut and spices.

instructions.text: Peel outer fibers from stem and chop finely.
Heat half the oil, add mustard seeds until crackling.
Add stem pieces, curry, salt, and chili powder.
Cover and simmer until soft (approximately one hour).
Grind coconut and garlic together.
When stem is almost cooked, add coconut-garlic mixture and continue cooking covered.
Finish with remaining coconut oil and let rest before serving.

recipes.title: Banana Flower Stir Fry
recipes.description: Indian-style banana flower stir fry with lentils.

instructions.text: Cook lentils separately.
Remove outer petals from flower; chop inner cream portion finely.
Apply coconut oil to palms and rub chopped flower to remove lumps.
Heat oil and splutter mustard seeds. Add chillies, onion, curry leaves; sauté until onions brown.
Add flower, garlic, spices, and salt. Cook covered 5 minutes without water.
Stir in lentils and cook 5 more minutes until dry.

notes: Optional: soak chopped flower in milk to reduce bitterness

recipes.title: Sautéed Lion's Mane Mushroom
recipes.description: Simple sautéed lion's mane mushroom with crab-like flavor.

instructions.text: Clean mushroom and slice or tear into pieces.
Sauté in real butter until golden and tender.
Serve immediately.

notes: Has a texture and flavor reminiscent of crab or lobster

recipes.title: Stir-Fried Lotus Root
recipes.description: Asian-style stir-fried lotus root with sesame and sake.

instructions.text: Slice lotus root crosswise into quarter-inch pieces.
Soak in water and change until water runs clear, then dry thoroughly.
Heat sesame oil and add lotus roots, tossing briefly.
Add remaining ingredients and stir continuously for approximately 10 minutes until the mixture reduces.
Serve warm. Reheats well.

notes: Lotus root discolors quickly - place cut pieces in water with lemon juice immediately

recipes.title: Creamed Bulrush
recipes.description: Tender bulrush shoots in a creamy white sauce.

instructions.text: Rinse shoots, steam with salt and water until limp. Drain, saving juice.
Chop shoots finely.
Melt butter in double boiler, stir in flour.
Gradually add juice and milk to reach 3 cups liquid, stirring constantly until smooth.
Season to taste. Garnish with egg slices.

recipes.title: Karela Bhaji (Pan-fried Bitter Melon)
recipes.description: Indian-style pan-fried bitter melon with aromatic spices.

instructions.text: Halve melon lengthwise; scrape out seeds and pith. Slice into 1/4-inch pieces.
Sprinkle with 1 tsp salt in a colander; drain 30 minutes. Squeeze and blot dry.
Warm ghee and oil until shimmering; toast cumin and fennel seeds ~30 seconds.
Add garlic and ginger; sauté 30 seconds.
Reduce heat to medium; add onion, coriander, turmeric, chili, pepper, and remaining salt. Sauté 6 minutes until softened.
Stir in melon and stock; sauté until tender and liquid mostly evaporates (~10 minutes), stirring often.
Add amchur and sugar; increase heat to high.
Pan-fry until liquid evaporates and melon crisps (~3 minutes), stirring frequently.
Season to taste; serve with cilantro.

recipes.title: Steamed Beets with Nasturtium
recipes.description: Tender beets with peppery nasturtium leaves and balsamic dressing.

instructions.text: Steam peeled beets until fork-tender (about 30 minutes).
Cool and cut into bite-sized wedges.
Whisk olive oil, balsamic vinegar, and salt together.
Sprinkle shredded nasturtium leaves over beets.
Drizzle with dressing and decorate with flowers.

recipes.title: Akebi Pod Miso Itame
recipes.description: Japanese stir-fried chocolate vine pods with miso.

instructions.text: Optionally soak pod halves in warm water for 30-60 minutes to reduce bitterness; pat dry.
Combine all liquid ingredients in a bowl, dissolving the miso paste and sugar together.
Heat oil in a fry pan. Add sliced akebi pod and sauté covered until softened, approximately 2 minutes.
Pour in the liquid mixture, reduce heat, and simmer until most liquid evaporates (1-2 minutes). Monitor closely to prevent burning.
Serve on a plate; garnish with chopped shiso leaf if desired.

recipes.title: Spiced Tindora Curry (Ivy Gourd)
recipes.description: Indian-style spiced ivy gourd (tindora) curry.

instructions.text: Heat oil in medium non-stick pan over medium heat.
Add mustard seeds; allow to pop.
Add cumin seeds; let sizzle.
Add asafoetida, turmeric, green chilies, and tindora; mix well.
Season with salt, red chili powder, coriander, and cumin powder.
Cover and cook until tindora becomes tender, stirring every few minutes.
Uncover and cook additional minutes to lightly brown.

notes: Use the slicer blade of your food processor to quickly slice the tindora
Cleaned, cut tindora freezes well

recipes.title: Fried Morels
recipes.attribution: Foxfire Book of Wild Plant Foods
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Wild Plant Foods
recipes.description: Simple pan-fried morel mushrooms, a springtime delicacy.

instructions.text: Clean morels by soaking briefly in salted water to remove insects.
Slice larger morels in half lengthwise.
Melt butter in skillet over medium heat.
Add morels and sauté until golden, about 5-7 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper and serve immediately.

notes: Always positively identify morels - never eat wild mushrooms unless certain

recipes.title: Stuffed Morels
recipes.attribution: Foxfire Book of Wild Plant Foods
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Wild Plant Foods
recipes.description: Morel mushrooms stuffed with a savory sausage filling.

instructions.text: Clean morels carefully, keeping them whole.
Brown sausage with onion; drain fat.
Mix sausage with cream cheese and bread crumbs.
Stuff mixture into morel cavities.
Bake at 350°F for 15-20 minutes until heated through.

notes: Can substitute other mild cheese for cream cheese

recipes.title: Appalachian Cottage Cheese
recipes.attribution: Foxfire 4 - Mrs. Harriet Echols & Mrs. Nora Garland
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian cottage cheese from Foxfire 4
recipes.description: Simple homemade cottage cheese from clabbered raw milk.

instructions.text: Pour raw milk into enamel or metal pan. Set in warm place to sour slowly - 1-2 days.
After milk clabbers, lift off cream and refrigerate.
Heat skimmed clabbered milk over low fire until it curdles.
Pour into colander or cheesecloth to drain several hours, or hang in flour sack overnight.
Work cheese with hands or spoon, squeezing out remaining water.
Sprinkle in salt to taste. Mix in some sour cream if desired.
Package and refrigerate. Keeps several weeks.

notes: Mrs. Nora Garland hung curdled milk in a clean flour sack overnight to drain.

recipes.title: Mrs. Earp's Quick Cooked Cheese
recipes.description: A quick cheese that can be eaten right away, cooked in a skillet until it forms a cake.

instructions.text: Let cream rise on whole milk, skim it off for butter making.
Add 2-3 tablespoons buttermilk per gallon of skimmed milk and let sit out 2 days to sour and clabber.
Refrigerate clabbered milk until ready to use.
Pour 2 gallons clabbered milk into pan and heat until a little hotter than lukewarm.
Pour into cloth-lined strainer. Gather corners and squeeze whey through, leaving curds.
Put curds in bowl, add salt and raw egg. Mix with hands.
Melt butter in large iron frying pan.
Add curds and keep turning over medium heat until all curds melt together into a cake.
Turn out into dish to cool. It will form a cake as it cools.

notes: Can be eaten right away or kept several days.
Gets firm enough to slice after drying somewhat.
Keeps about a week.

recipes.title: Mrs. Reese's Block Cheese
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian cheese-making from Foxfire 4, Vilas, North Carolina
recipes.description: Traditional rennet cheese pressed into firm blocks that keep well for a month or more.

instructions.text: Pour milk into a large pan and heat on wood stove until a little past lukewarm.
Remove from heat and add the dissolved rennet and color tablets.
Let sit 15-30 minutes until milk stiffens and becomes jellylike.
Cut with knife or spatula into tiny squares, also running spatula under surface as if cutting into layers.
Let sit briefly, then work mixture gently until broken into pieces about the size of corn kernels.
Return pan to stove and heat slowly until almost as hot as touch can stand (not boiling), stirring constantly.
Remove from heat and let sit 15-30 minutes to cool.
Strain through cheesecloth in colander. Let drip naturally (don't squeeze).
Return curds to pan, add salt, and massage in well.
Put into cheesecloth-lined press. Add weight in stages and leave overnight (12 hours).
Remove from press and dry in open air for one week, turning twice daily.

notes: Before rennet tablets, a small piece of dried cow stomach lining was used.
Cheese keeps well for a month or more.
